Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Situation2: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Story: The dashboard clock blinked 5:45 PM as I navigated the evening traffic, my phone buzzing with two different notifications. My daughter’s message popped up first: “Mom, don’t forget our family call tonight! Everyone’s excited to see you before the holiday.” I could almost hear my grandchildren’s laughter, the warmth of their voices a comfort I cherished. But then, the taxi app chimed in—my next passenger, Mr. Lee, was already waiting, his messages growing more insistent: “Please hurry, I can’t be late!” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me. My family expected me to be present, to keep our tradition alive, to show I cared. But Mr. Lee expected professionalism, punctuality, the reliability that kept my ratings high and my income steady. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, heart tugged in two directions, wondering how I could possibly be the grandmother my family needed and the driver my passenger demanded—all at the same time.
